RobotClient

Class SimpleRobotClient

  • java.lang.Object
    • RobotClient.SimpleRobotClient

  • public class SimpleRobotClient
extends java.lang.Object

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      SimpleRobotClient()
      Starts the SimpleRobotClient by running a GUI with the APPLICATION_NAME (Currently "My First Robot Program").
      SimpleRobotClient(java.lang.String applicationName)
      Starts the SimpleRobotClient by running a GUI titled by the String applicationName.
      SimpleRobotClient(java.lang.String applicationName, java.lang.String peerHostname)
      Starts the SimpleRobotClient by running a GUI titled by the String applicationName and attempts to automatically connect (using Direct Connect) to a robot specified by the given peerHostname.

    • Constructor Detail

      • SimpleRobotClient

        public SimpleRobotClient()
        Starts the SimpleRobotClient by running a GUI with the APPLICATION_NAME (Currently "My First Robot Program").

      • SimpleRobotClient

        public SimpleRobotClient(java.lang.String applicationName)
        Starts the SimpleRobotClient by running a GUI titled by the String applicationName.
        Parameters:
        applicationName - String text which sets the title of the RobotClient GUI

      • SimpleRobotClient

        public SimpleRobotClient(java.lang.String applicationName,
                 java.lang.String peerHostname)
        Starts the SimpleRobotClient by running a GUI titled by the String applicationName and attempts to automatically connect (using Direct Connect) to a robot specified by the given peerHostname. This constructor allows you to quickly connect to a robot without having to use the connection wizard.
        Parameters:
        applicationName - String text which sets the title of the RobotClient GUI
        peerHostname - Hostname or IP address of the robot to connect to.

    • Method Detail

      • buttonState

        public boolean buttonState()
        Returns the value of the play/stop button. If 'Play' was most recently pressed, it will return true. If 'Stop' was most recently pressed, it will return false.
        Returns:
        the state of the Play/Stop button

      • isStopped

        public boolean isStopped()
        Returns:
        true if 'stop' was most recently pressed, false otherwise.

      • isPlaying

        public boolean isPlaying()
        Returns:
        true if 'play' was most recently pressed, false otherwise.

      • waitForPlay

        public void waitForPlay()
        Blocks any further program operation until the play button is pressed.

      • waitForStop

        public void waitForStop()
        Blocks any further program operation until the stop button is pressed.

      • sleepUnlessStop

        public boolean sleepUnlessStop(int ms)
        Sleeps the program for a given number of milliseconds. If the Stop button is pressed, this method immediately exits without sleeping.
        Parameters:
        ms - Number of milliseconds to sleep the program for

        Writes the message string to the GUI's textbox. The message is always preceded by a timestamp.
        Parameters:
        message - String containing information to be written to the GUI textbox

      • moveMotor

        public void moveMotor(int motorId,
             int velocity)
        Moves the motor specified by the given motorId at the given velocity.
        Parameters:
        motorId - The id of the motor to command - valid range is 0 to 3
        velocity - The velocity of the motor.

      • moveMotors

        public void moveMotors(int leftMotorVelocity,
              int rightMotorVelocity)
        Moves motor 0 at the velocity specified by leftMotorVelocity and motor 1 at the velocity specified by rightMotorVelocity.
        Parameters:
        leftMotorVelocity - Velocity to set motor 0 to
        rightMotorVelocity - Velocity to set motor 1 to

      • moveMotors

        public void moveMotors(int leftMotorVelocity,
              int rightMotorVelocity,
              int runningTime)
        Moves motor 0 at the velocity specified by leftMotorVelocity and motor 1 at the velocity specified by rightMotorVelocity for the amount of time specified by runningTime, after which motor 0 and motor 1 are set to 0 velocity.
        Parameters:
        leftMotorVelocity - Velocity to set motor 0 to
        rightMotorVelocity - Velocity to set motor 1 to
        runningTime - Time in milliseconds to run motors for

      • stopMotors

        public void stopMotors()
        Sets all four Qwerk motor ports to 0 velocity.

      • setServo

        public void setServo(int servoId,
            int position)
        Sets the servo specified by the given servoId to the given position.
        Parameters:
        servoId - The ID of the servo to be commanded - valid range is 0 to 15
        position - The position to set the servo to - valid range is 0 to 255

      • analog

        public short analog(int analogInputPortId)
        Returns the value of the analog input specified by the given port id. The value returned is the measured voltage in millivolts. For example, a reading of 2.5V will come back as 2500.
        Parameters:
        analogInputPortId - The analog port ID from which to get a sensor value from - valid range is 0 to 7
        Returns:
        The value of the voltage at analog port ID in millivolts

      • digital

        public boolean digital(int digitalInputPortId)
        Returns the value of the digital input specified by the given port id. The method returns true if a high signal is detected at the input port, and false if a low signal is detected.
        Parameters:
        digitalInputPortId - The ID of the digital input port to read from
        Returns:
        The state of the input port specified by ID

      • setDigital

        public void setDigital(boolean state,
              int digitalOutputPortId)
        Sets the given digital output to a given state.
        Parameters:
        state - The state to set the ouput to - true corresponds to a high output signal and false to a low signal.
        digitalOutputPortId - The output port to set

      • setDigitalOn

        public void setDigitalOn(int digitalOutputPortId)
        Sets the given digital output to on (or high) using setDigital.

      • setDigitalOff

        public void setDigitalOff(int digitalOutputPortId)
        Sets the given digital output to off (or low) using setDigital.

      • setLED

        public void setLED(edu.cmu.ri.mrpl.TeRK.LEDMode mode,
          int ledId)
        Sets the given LED to a given state. The modes are defined by the mode variable, and include LEDMode.LEDOn, LEDMode.LEDOff, and LEDMode.LEDBlinking.
        Parameters:
        mode - The mode to set the LED to (LEDMode.LEDOn, LEDMode.LEDOff, and LEDMode.LEDBlinking)
        ledId - The ID of the LED to set. The valid range is 0 to 9.

      • setLEDOn

        public void setLEDOn(int ledId)
        Sets the LED specified by the given id to on.
        Parameters:
        ledId - The ID of the LED to turn on, valid range is 0 to 9

      • setLEDOff

        public void setLEDOff(int ledId)
        Sets the LED specified by the given id to off.
        Parameters:
        ledId - The ID of the LED to turn off, valid range is 0 to 9

      • setLEDBlinking

        public void setLEDBlinking(int ledId)
        Sets the LED specified by the given id to blinking.
        Parameters:
        ledId - The ID of the LED to blink, valid range is 0 to 9

      • setLEDState

        public void setLEDState(boolean state,
               int ledId)
        Sets the LED specified by the given id to on if state is true; off otherwise.
        Parameters:
        state - Command the LED to on (true) or off (false)
        ledId - The ID of the LED to set

      • batteryVoltage

        public int batteryVoltage()
        Returns the voltage of the Qwerk's main power source in millivolts.
        Returns:
        Voltage of the Qwerk power source in millivolts

      • button

        public boolean button()
        Returns the current state of the Qwerk's config button.
        Returns:
        True if the button is currently depressed, false otherwise.

      • waitForButtonOrStop

        public boolean waitForButtonOrStop()
        Blocks until the config button is pressed and released or the user cancels by pressing the Stop button. Returns false if the method returns because the button was pressed, but returns true if it returns because the user pressed the Stop button during program execution.

        NOTE: This method determines whether the button is pressed (or released) by checking the state 20 times per second (i.e. every 50 milliseconds). Thus, if the button is pressed (or released) for less than 50 milliseconds, the change in button state may not be detected.
        Returns:
        True if the method returns because the GUI stop button is pressed, false if the config button is pressed.

      • playSound

        public void playSound(java.lang.String filePath)
        Plays the sound file specified by the given filePath. Only supports playback of PCM-encoded WAV files.

        Sounds are played asynchronously, meaning that this method will not block and wait while the sound is playing. Instead, it returns as soon as the sound file is transmitted to the Qwerk.

        Does nothing (other than log a message and print out an error) if the file cannot be read or played.
        Parameters:
        filePath - The path to the audio file to be played by the Qwerk. For example, "C:/sounds/monkey.wav".

      • playTone

        public final void playTone(int frequency,
            int amplitude,
            int duration)
        Plays the tone specified by the given frequency, amplitude, and duration. Tones are played asynchronously, meaning that this method will not block and wait while the tone is playing. Instead, it returns as soon as the command is transmitted to the Qwerk.
        Parameters:
        frequency - Frequency of the tone in Hz. Human hearing can detect frequencies between 20 and 20000 Hz, though frequencies above 15000 Hz just annoy teenagers and can't be heard by adults. Human speech is around 200-1000 Hz.
        amplitude - The volume of the tone to be played - 0 is no volume, 100 is maximum volume
        duration - The time for which to play the tone in milliseconds

      • playRoboticon

        public void playRoboticon(java.lang.String filename)
        Loads the roboticon (sequence or expression) having the given filename and plays it. If there exists both a sequence and an expression having the given filename, the sequence is played and the expression is ignored. Does nothing if the filename does not match any existing sequence or expression. Expressions are played at the speed defined by ExpressionSpeed.MEDIUM_VELOCITY.
        Parameters:
        filename - the name of the sequence or expression to be played.
